Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Brain, Mind, and Society: An Integrative Training Program in Valuation, Decision-making, and Social Exchange

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award supports the development of a multidisciplinary graduate training program in Brain, Mind, and Society. Its purpose is to provide students with the analytical foundations and the experimental skills needed to pursue scientific careers at the intersection of neuroscience and the social sciences, who are capable of integrating neural, psychological, and economic approaches to attack basic and applied problems related to valuation, human decision making, and social exchange. Trainees will take a rigorously designed, largely team-taught course sequence, spanning from nervous system organization and function to mathematical models of decision making and social exchange. This coursework will be complemented by equal balance in cross-disciplinary laboratory research, thereby tightly integrating research training with scholarship to create true intellectual hybrids across both disciplines.
The Brain, Mind, and Society program emphasizes the inclusion of highly qualified underrepresented students through a four-tiered outreach program, Science Matters, involving a team-based mentorship program bringing together students from the this program, underrepresented undergraduate students at Cal State University, Los Angeles and underrepresented high school students in Los Angeles' Belmont Schools. The resulting diversity of the program's collaborative teams will reflect the program's broader impact in five key social application areas, which may ultimately provide a new scientifically-enriched discourse to help us understand critical social problems, in economic, therapeutic, educational, philosophical, and business and political applications. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Every decision we make, from small, everyday decisions about what to have for lunch to consequential decisions about purchasing a home or saving for retirement is the result of incredibly complex brain processes. In fact, many decisions we make don’t happen in isolation, but involve social interactions, spanning from small groups, such as the family, work teams, and juries, to whole societies, such as financial markets and politics. Until recently, these different levels of human decision-making were studied by many different disciplines, such as psychology, economics, and political science and typically did not make contact with the brain. In recent years, however, unprecedented advances in the brain science of decision-making, emerging new technologies for probing the human brain, and a growing interest in merging various disciplinary perspectives has led to exciting new interdisciplinary possibilities and collaborations. Our NSF Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship was created in 2007 by our recognition of the need for interdisciplinary training to create the next generation of researchers who would solidify these interdisciplinary possibilities into new scientific fields, such as neuroeconomics. 

 

Since 2007, trainees in our PhD program have acquired the new skills required for this interdisciplinary research through a new core course sequence, providing exposure to core constructs in economics, psychology and computational neuroscience. They have also been immersed in laboratory experiences to learn basic techniques such as computational modeling, functional neuroimaging and neuropsychological assessment. Through this interdisciplinary training, they have made important discoveries. To highlight just a few, Cary Frydman used brain imaging in combination with financial markets to test theories of investor behavior and why investors sometimes make poor financial decisions. Ben Bushong discovered why our physical proximity to goods, such as food within reach, can have such a hold on us by cueing a Pavlovian brain reward system that encodes basic rewards necessary for survival. These cues relate directly to our economic decision-making and can result in our willingness to spend significantly more for an item. Alice Lin discovered that individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) process social rewards differently than do individuals without autism spectrum disorder. Alice examined reward learning in the brain and found substantial overlap in the neural circuitry associated with social and non-social reward processing. This itself is important because it suggests the brain uses a common neural currency to represent rewards. In individuals with autism spectrum disorder, Alice found that key reward areas of the brain were less active, suggesting that social impairments may stem from more general reward processing impairments. 

 

These three highlights of the discoveries trainees have made during the course of our training program illustrate not just the contributions this new interdisciplinary research makes to our understanding of central scientific mysteries of human decision-making and social life. It also shows the potential this new research holds for addressing social issues of critical importance, from how we can make better consumer decisions and fulfill our long-term goals to how we may make better social policy and understand and treat mental illnesses and diseases.
